qas.question: When did the US DOT combine major federal responsibilities for air and surface transport?
What did the Federal Aviation Agency change it's name to?
Who would the FAA administrator report to?
Who approves new programs and budget requests?
Who is the final person to approve the budget that is submitted?
What did the Federal Aviation Agency change it's name from?
Who would the secretary of transport report to instead of the FAA?

plausible_answers.text: Federal Highway Administration, Federal Railroad Administration, the Coast Guard, and the Saint Lawrence Seaway Commission

qas.question: What agencies combined to make the Federal Aviation Administration?
Who did the secretary of transportation send budget requests to to be approved?

context: In <a0_0>1967<a0_0/>, a new U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) combined major federal responsibilities for air and surface transport. The Federal Aviation Agency's name changed to the <a1_0><b5_0>Federal Aviation Administration<b5_0/><a1_0/> as it became one of several agencies (e.g., <b7_0>Federal Highway Administration, Federal Railroad Administration, the Coast Guard, and the Saint Lawrence Seaway Commission<b7_0/>) within DOT (albeit the largest). The FAA administrator would no longer report directly to the <b6_0>president<b6_0/> but would instead report to the <a2_0>Secretary of Transportation<a2_0/>. New programs and budget requests would have to be approved by <a3_0><b8_0>DOT<b8_0/><a3_0/>, which would then include these requests in the overall budget and submit it to the <a4_0>president<a4_0/>.
